intro: Brassica varia var. campestre, commonly known as the wild cabbage, is a herbaceous biennial plant native to Europe. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, four-petaled flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, with serrated, edible leaves that are often used in traditional cuisine. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found along roadsides and in waste areas. Its genetic diversity has made it an important species in the study of plant evolution and domestication.
